REASONING — your explanation of WHY the evidence proves the claim. Without reasoning, evidence just sits there; you must connect it to your argument.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide breaks down the three super important parts of a body paragraph: the Claim, which is like your mini-argument for the paragraph; the Evidence, which is the proof like a fact or quote to back up your claim; and the Reasoning, which is where you explain *why* that proof totally supports your argument. You have to connect the dots for your reader, or the evidence won't make sense.

slides.text: Choosing strong evidence: A statistic is powerful but must come from a credible source. An expert quote adds authority. A specific example makes the abstract concrete. The best paragraphs use multiple types of evidence working together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about picking the best proof, or evidence. A statistic can be super powerful if it's from a good source, and an expert's quote makes your argument sound really smart and official. Using a specific example is also great because it helps paint a picture for your reader, and the best paragraphs often mix and match these to make them super strong.

slides.text: The reasoning is where YOUR thinking shines. Weak reasoning restates the evidence. Strong reasoning explains significance: why the data matters, what it implies, and how it connects to your larger argument.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where your own smart thinking really comes in! Reasoning isn't just repeating the evidence you found; it's about explaining *why* that evidence is important and how it proves your point. Think about what the statistic or quote *means* and how it connects directly to your main argument.

slides.text: Transition words are the glue between paragraphs. To ADD: furthermore, additionally, moreover. To CONTRAST: however, on the other hand, nevertheless. To show CAUSE: therefore, consequently, as a result. Strong transitions make your essay flow like a conversation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Think of transition words like the bridges connecting different islands in your essay – they make it easy for your reader to get from one idea to the next without getting lost. Words like "furthermore" or "in addition" help you add more points, while "however" or "on the other hand" show a contrast, and "therefore" or "as a result" show a cause and effect.

slides.prompt: Draft two body paragraphs for your persuasive essay: (1) Write your thesis at the top. (2) Begin each paragraph with a claim that supports your thesis. (3) Include at least one piece of evidence from the packet. (4) Write 2-3 sentences of reasoning. (5) Use a transition word between paragraphs. (6) Exchange with a partner for CER feedback.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put it all together and start writing! Grab your thesis statement, then write two body paragraphs, making sure each has a clear claim, some solid evidence from our packet, and at least two sentences explaining your reasoning. Don't forget to use a transition word to link them, and then you'll swap with a friend to get some feedback.

slides.text: The CER structure transforms opinions into arguments. Anyone can state a claim, but only a skilled writer backs it up with evidence and explains why it matters.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student construct body paragraphs with clear claims, relevant evidence, and logical reasoning that connects back to the thesis?
slides.mascot_explanation: We just learned how to turn our opinions into really strong arguments using the CER structure, which is awesome! You can now build paragraphs that don't just state an idea, but actually prove it with solid evidence and smart explanations, making your persuasive essays way more convincing. You've totally got this!

parent_notes: The claim-evidence-reasoning structure is used throughout middle school and high school writing. It teaches students that an opinion is not enough — they must support their thinking with evidence and explain their logic. Practice at home by asking your child to support their opinions with evidence in conversation. The globalization evidence packet provides age-appropriate data and examples.

title: Adding and Subtracting Integers — Rules and Real-World Applications
description: Students build on their number line understanding of integers to learn the rules for adding and subtracting positive and negative numbers. They apply these skills to real-world contexts including temperature changes, financial transactions, and elevation differences.
instructions:
1. Review integers on the number line from Day 2.
2. Model integer addition using number line movements: positive equals move right, negative equals move left.
3. Discover the rule: adding a negative is the same as subtracting.
4. Practice adding integers with same signs and different signs.
5. Model integer subtraction: subtracting a negative is the same as adding.
6. Practice subtraction by rewriting as addition of the opposite.
7. Apply to temperature changes and financial scenarios.
8. Apply to elevation differences and depth calculations.
9. Students solve mixed integer addition and subtraction problems.
10. Challenge: multi-step problems combining addition and subtraction of integers.

slides.heading: Integer Operations
slides.subheading: Adding and Subtracting Positive and Negative Numbers
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today. It's telling us we're going to learn about "Integer Operations," which is just a fancy way of saying how we add and subtract numbers that can be positive or negative, like temperatures or money. Think of it as learning the secret handshake for working with numbers that go below zero.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out a large number line on the floor from -20 to +20. Prepare two-color counters where yellow represents positive and red represents negative. Print integer operation reference cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this activity, we've got some cool tools! We have a big number line on the floor so we can actually walk our steps, some colored counters where yellow means positive and red means negative, a card with the rules on it, a calculator to double-check our work, and a worksheet with problems. Go grab all of these things with a grown-up, and then lay out that number line so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Adding integers with the SAME sign: Just add the absolute values and keep the sign. (+5) + (+3) = +8. (-5) + (-3) = -8. Think of it as combining groups moving in the same direction.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about adding numbers that are going in the same direction. If you're adding two positive numbers, it's like taking steps forward, so you just add them up and stay positive. If you're adding two negative numbers, it's like taking steps backward twice, so you add their sizes but stay in the negative zone. It's like if you owe someone $5 and then borrow another $3, you now owe $8.

slides.text: Adding integers with DIFFERENT signs: Subtract the smaller absolute value from the larger, and keep the sign of the larger. (+7) + (-4) = +3. (-7) + (+4) = -3. Think of it as a tug-of-war between positive and negative.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at adding numbers that are pulling in opposite directions, like a tug-of-war. When you add a positive and a negative number, you figure out which one is stronger (the one with the bigger absolute value) and that side wins, keeping its sign. So, if you have $7 and spend $4, you still have $3 left. If you owe $7 and pay back $4, you still owe $3.

slides.text: Subtracting integers: CHANGE to addition of the opposite. 5 - 8 becomes 5 + (-8) = -3. (-3) - (-7) becomes (-3) + (+7) = +4. Keep-Change-Change: Keep the first number, Change subtraction to addition, Change the sign of the second number.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important trick for subtraction: instead of subtracting a number, you can add its opposite! So, if you see "5 minus 8," you can change it to "5 plus negative 8," and then you're back to the tug-of-war rule we just learned. Remember "Keep-Change-Change": keep the first number, change the subtraction sign to addition, and change the sign of the number you were subtracting.

slides.text: Real-world integer problems: Temperature at dawn is -8 degrees. By noon it rises 15 degrees: -8 + 15 = 7 degrees. A submarine at -200 meters rises 75 meters: -200 + 75 = -125 meters. Your bank has $120 and you spend $85 then $50: 120 + (-85) + (-50) = -15 (overdrawn).
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how these number rules pop up in real life! For example, if it's freezing at -8 degrees and the temperature goes up 15 degrees, you're just doing -8 + 15 to find the new temperature. It's the same idea for a submarine going up from a deep depth or when your bank account goes up and down with spending and deposits.

slides.prompt: Solve these integer problems: (1) Temperature: Starting at -12 degrees, it rises 8, drops 15, rises 22. Final temperature? (2) Elevation: Start at 500 feet, descend 600, climb 350. Final elevation? (3) Finance: Start with $200. Transactions: -$45, +$30, -$120, -$25, +$80. Final balance? (4) Create 5 real-world integer problems and solve them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to try it out! For the temperature problem, imagine you're on that number line and take steps for each change. For the elevation and finance problems, think about whether you're going up or down, spending or earning. For the last part, get creative and make up your own scenarios – maybe about video game scores or how much candy you have left!

slides.text: Integer operations follow logical rules that connect to the real world. Temperatures go below zero, accounts can be overdrawn, and elevations go below sea level. Understanding WHY the rules work gives you true mathematical power.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student add and subtract integers fluently using both rules and number line reasoning, and apply these operations to real-world contexts?
slides.mascot_explanation: We just finished a whole bunch of adding and subtracting with positive and negative numbers! You learned how the rules work for numbers going the same way, opposite ways, and even how to handle subtraction by changing it to addition. You saw how this all connects to things like the weather, money, and how high or low things are, which is pretty cool math power!

parent_notes: Integer operations are a major milestone in mathematical development. The Keep-Change-Change rule is a useful shortcut, but understanding WHY it works through number line reasoning builds deeper comprehension. Practice at home with weather reports, bank statements, or elevation maps.

title: Globalization and Culture — How Ideas, Food, and Music Cross Borders
description: Students explore cultural globalization by examining how food, music, language, and ideas have spread across borders. They analyze the benefits of cultural exchange alongside concerns about cultural homogenization and the loss of local traditions.
instructions:
1. Review economic globalization from Day 1.
2. Introduce cultural globalization: the spread of ideas, customs, and traditions.
3. Trace specific examples: pizza from Italy, K-pop from Korea to global audiences.
4. Discuss cultural exchange vs. cultural appropriation.
5. Examine technology's role in cultural spread: social media, streaming.
6. Discuss cultural homogenization: Is the world becoming too similar?
7. Examine resistance: language preservation, local food movements.
8. Students map the cultural origins of items in their daily lives.
9. Create a cultural exchange web showing connections between countries.
10. Debate: Does globalization enrich or diminish world cultures?

slides.heading: Cultural Globalization
slides.subheading: How Ideas, Food, and Music Cross Borders
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our lesson, introducing the big idea: cultural globalization. It's all about how things like food, music, and even ideas travel all around the world and connect people, even if they live super far apart. Think about your favorite song that's popular everywhere, or a food you love that originally came from another country – that's cultural globalization in action!

slides.setup_instructions: Mount a large world map on a board. Prepare cultural exchange example cards with photographs. Have colored string ready for mapping connections.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we're gathering our tools for our activity. We've got a big world map to show where things come from, example cards with pictures to spark ideas, research cards to help us find out origins, colored string and pushpins to connect everything on the map, and a journal with pencils and markers to write down our findings. You'll need to get all these things ready to go so we can start building our cultural connections.

slides.text: Cultural globalization is the worldwide spread of ideas, customs, and traditions. Your favorite pizza evolved from Italian flatbread using tomatoes from the Americas. Your smartphone was designed in California, assembled in China, using minerals from Congo. Culture flows in every direction.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains what cultural globalization actually means. It's like when a cool idea or tradition from one place catches on in another, spreading everywhere. The slide uses pizza as a perfect example – it started in Italy but now people all over the world eat and love it, and your phone is another great example of how different countries contribute to one item. So, culture isn't just stuck in one place; it's constantly moving!

slides.text: Technology accelerates cultural exchange exponentially. A Korean pop song can go viral worldwide in hours. A cooking technique shared on YouTube reaches millions. Social media connects teenagers across continents in real time. This speed of cultural exchange has no historical precedent.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this slide is all about how super-fast technology makes cultural globalization happen even quicker. Think about how a song from Korea can become a worldwide hit overnight, or how you can learn a new dance from a video someone posted online. Social media and streaming services are like superhighways for culture, letting ideas and trends zoom around the planet faster than ever before.

slides.text: Cultural exchange raises concerns. Cultural homogenization means the world is becoming more similar: same fast food, movies, and brands everywhere. Some worry unique local cultures are being drowned out. Language loss is a crisis: a language dies approximately every two weeks worldwide.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part talks about some worries that come with so much culture spreading around. It's called cultural homogenization, which basically means the world might start to feel a bit too similar, with the same stores and entertainment everywhere. We'll also talk about how some languages are disappearing because they aren't being used as much, which is a real bummer.

slides.text: Many communities actively resist homogenization. France limits English in official documents. Indigenous peoples fight to preserve languages. The slow food movement promotes local cuisine. Cultural preservation and exchange can coexist — the goal is balance, not isolation.
slides.mascot_explanation: But don't worry, it's not all about things becoming the same! This slide shows that lots of people are working hard to keep their unique cultures alive and well. Some countries have rules to protect their language, and there are movements focused on celebrating local foods. It's about finding a way to share and learn from each other without losing what makes each culture special.

slides.prompt: Complete three tasks: (1) Cultural inventory: List 10 daily items, research their origins, create a chart. (2) Cultural web: Use colored string on the map to connect countries sharing cultural elements. (3) Position paper: Does cultural globalization enrich or diminish world cultures? Support with specific examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time for the fun part – the activity! You'll first make a list of 10 things you use every day and figure out where they came from, then put that in a chart. Next, you'll use the string on the map to show how different countries are connected through culture. Finally, you'll write down your own thoughts on whether all this global sharing is good or bad for world cultures, using examples from our lesson.

slides.text: Cultural globalization makes the world smaller and more connected. The challenge is to enjoy cultural exchange while respecting and preserving the unique traditions that give each culture its identity.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain cultural globalization with examples, analyze benefits and concerns, and form a supported position?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide wraps things up, reminding us that cultural globalization is making our world feel smaller and more connected. The big challenge is figuring out how we can enjoy all these cool new ideas and foods from everywhere while still making sure we don't forget or lose the special traditions that make each place unique. It's all about finding that good balance between sharing and preserving.

parent_notes: Cultural globalization is highly relatable since your child experiences it daily. The cultural inventory often surprises students when they realize how many items come from other cultures. Encourage exploration of your family's own cultural origins and traditions.

title: Global Trade Routes — How Goods Move Around the World
description: Students map and analyze major global trade routes, understanding how goods move from production to consumption. They examine shipping lanes, trade agreements, and the geographic factors that influence international trade patterns.
instructions:
1. Review urbanization patterns from Day 1.
2. Introduce global trade routes: paths goods travel from producer to consumer.
3. Trace a product's journey: a t-shirt from cotton field to closet.
4. Map major shipping lanes: Pacific, Atlantic, Suez Canal, Panama Canal.
5. Discuss geographic chokepoints: Strait of Hormuz, Strait of Malacca.
6. Examine how geography influences trade: ports, rivers, proximity.
7. Study trade agreements and regional blocs (EU, USMCA).
8. Students trace a supply chain on a world map.
9. Calculate distances and shipping times between major ports.
10. Discuss how disruptions affect global trade.

slides.heading: Global Trade Routes
slides.subheading: How Goods Move Around the World
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: something called "Global Trade Routes," which is basically how all the stuff we buy gets from where it's made all the way to us. Think about all the things you own – this lesson will show you the amazing journey they took to get to you.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a large world map showing major ocean shipping routes. Print supply chain examples. Have trade route overlay transparencies ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists all the cool tools we'll need for our adventure today. We've got a big world map to see where things go, special see-through sheets called transparencies to layer on top, examples of how products travel, colored pencils and rulers for drawing and measuring, a calculator for some math, an atlas for looking up places, and regular pencils for writing. Make sure you have all these ready before we start.

slides.text: Over 80% of global trade travels by sea. Massive container ships carry goods on routes following ocean currents, wind patterns, and strategic waterways. A single container ship can carry 20,000 containers — enough to fill a train 44 miles long.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this is telling us that most of the world's stuff travels on giant ships across the ocean – like, seriously, over 80% of it! Imagine a container ship so big it could hold 20,000 shipping containers, which is like a train that's 44 miles long. We'll be looking at how these ships navigate the oceans and why they follow certain paths.

slides.text: Geographic chokepoints are narrow passages controlling trade flow. The Suez Canal saves ships a 6,000-mile trip around Africa. The Strait of Malacca carries 25% of world trade. When the Ever Given blocked the Suez Canal in 2021, it cost billions per day.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about "chokepoints," which are like narrow doorways for ships that control a ton of trade. The Suez Canal is a big one because it cuts off thousands of miles of travel, and the Strait of Malacca is super important too. It even mentions how a single ship getting stuck can cause huge problems, which shows how vital these passages are for getting goods everywhere.

slides.text: A t-shirt's journey: Cotton grown in India, shipped to Bangladesh for spinning, cut and sewn in Vietnam, buttons from China, labels from Indonesia, shipped to the US, trucked to your store. Your $15 shirt has traveled over 15,000 miles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here’s a cool example: they’re showing us how a simple t-shirt travels all over the world before it gets to you! The cotton might grow in one country, get spun into thread in another, sewn into the shirt in a third, and then shipped to your store. It’s pretty wild to think your t-shirt might have traveled over 15,000 miles before you even bought it.

slides.text: Trade agreements shape geography. The EU allows free trade among 27 nations. USMCA connects US, Mexico, and Canada. These agreements create blocs where goods flow freely within the group but face tariffs from outside.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is about trade agreements, which are like special deals countries make with each other to make trading easier. Think of groups like the European Union (EU) where countries trade freely among themselves, or the USMCA agreement between the US, Mexico, and Canada. These deals can make it easier for goods to move between those countries, but sometimes harder to trade with countries outside the agreement.

slides.prompt: Map a global supply chain: (1) Choose a product: smartphone, chocolate, sneakers, or bicycle. (2) Research where components are sourced. Identify at least 5 countries. (3) Draw the route on a world map. (4) Calculate total distance. (5) Identify chokepoints. (6) Write about what happens if one link is disrupted.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to do some exploring ourselves! We get to pick a product, like a smartphone or some cool sneakers, and then we'll trace its journey across the globe on our map, figuring out where all its parts came from. We’ll draw the route, calculate the distance, and even think about what happens if one of those places has a problem.

slides.text: Every product connects you to a global network of farms, factories, ships, and trade routes. Understanding these connections reveals the complexity of the modern economy.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student map major trade routes, identify chokepoints, trace a supply chain, and analyze trade network vulnerability?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us that everything we buy connects us to a huge worldwide network of people and places, from farms to factories to all those big ships. It's pretty amazing to think about how all these different parts work together to get us the things we use every day. You've just learned how to map out these routes, trace a product's life story, and understand why these connections are so important!

parent_notes: Supply chain mapping makes abstract economics tangible. Check product labels at home to reveal global connections. The chokepoints discussion helps children understand why certain locations have outsized geopolitical importance.

title: The Crossover — Pages 51-100: Rules, Rivalry, and Family Bonds
description: Students continue reading The Crossover by Kwame Alexander, focusing on the growing tension between twin brothers Josh and Jordan. They analyze basketball metaphors exploring family relationships and discuss the verse novel form.
instructions:
