2. Read aloud pages 51-100 with attention to rhythm and line breaks.
3. Discuss the growing tension between Josh and Jordan.
4. Analyze the basketball rules structuring the novel.
5. Examine the verse novel form and its effect on reading.
6. Discuss the father's character: strengths and emerging concerns.
7. Identify literary devices: metaphor, simile, alliteration.
8. Students choose a favorite passage and analyze its techniques.
9. Practice reading a passage aloud following the poet's line breaks.
10. Journal: Write about a time when rivalry or competition affected you.

slides.heading: The Crossover
slides.subheading: Pages 51-100: Rules, Rivalry, and Family
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing the section we're diving into, all about "The Crossover," focusing on pages 51 through 100. It tells us we'll be exploring the rules of the story, the rivalry between the main characters, and how family plays a role. Think of it as the title card for this part of our reading adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Have copies bookmarked at page 51. Prepare character tracking journals. Print literary devices reference cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need to gather our tools. We've got the book, "The Crossover," which is our main guide. We'll also need a journal to keep track of characters, a reference card that explains literary terms (like metaphors and similes), and a handout about poetic techniques. Don't forget your pencils to jot down notes! Make sure you have all these things ready before we move on.

slides.text: The Crossover is a verse novel — a story told entirely in poetry. Kwame Alexander uses short lines, white space, and rhythm to control pacing. When basketball action speeds up, lines get shorter. When emotions run deep, the lines slow down.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this slide is explaining that "The Crossover" isn't a regular story; it's written like a poem, which is called a verse novel. The author, Kwame Alexander, uses short lines and spaces really carefully, kind of like how a basketball player uses quick moves. When the action in the book gets fast, the lines in the poem get shorter, and when things get emotional, the lines slow down, making you feel the story more deeply.

slides.text: The basketball rules opening each section are metaphors for life. A crossover is the most effective basketball move — but also about crossing from childhood to adolescence. Look for how each rule connects to what happens in the chapter.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a cool part where we look at the basketball rules at the beginning of each section. The slide says these rules are like secret messages, or metaphors, for what's happening in the story and in life. A "crossover" in basketball is a fancy move, but here it also represents the twins growing up and changing. We need to think about how each rule connects to the events and feelings in the chapters.

slides.text: Sibling rivalry is one of literature's oldest stories. Josh and Jordan are identical twins growing apart. What causes the rift? How does competition change their relationship? Pay attention to what each brother wants.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're focusing on the brothers, Josh and Jordan, and how they're starting to fight. Sibling rivalry is super common, and the slide points out that these twins, who are basically identical, are beginning to go in different directions. We need to pay close attention to what's causing this tension and what each brother really wants, because that's what drives their conflict.

slides.text: Reading poetry aloud requires attention to the poet's choices. Where a line breaks matters. A short line gets emphasis. Enjambment creates momentum. Follow the line breaks, pause at white space, feel the rhythm.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about *how* we read poetry. It's telling us that where the author decides to break a line in a poem is important – it can make certain words stand out or create a feeling of speed. So, when we read aloud, we need to follow those breaks, pause where there's empty space, and really try to feel the rhythm, just like listening to a song.

slides.prompt: Reading response: (1) Choose a favorite passage (at least 10 lines). Copy it and identify every literary device. (2) Practice reading it aloud three times following line breaks. Perform for a partner. (3) Journal: Write about a time competition with a sibling or friend created tension. How does your experience connect to the story?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for you to get creative! You'll pick a part of the book you really liked, write it down, and find all the cool literary tricks the author used. Then, you'll practice reading that passage aloud a few times, paying close attention to those line breaks we just talked about. Finally, you'll write in your journal about a time you felt competitive with someone and how it made you feel, connecting it back to the story.

slides.text: Alexander proves poetry can capture basketball's speed, sibling rivalry's heat, and growing up's complexity. The verse novel form creates a faster, more emotional, more musical reading experience.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify literary devices in the verse novel, analyze how poetic form enhances storytelling, and connect themes to personal experience?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is like a summary of what we've learned and what we've accomplished. It reminds us that the author did an amazing job using poetry to show the fast pace of basketball, the intensity of sibling fights, and the complicated feelings of growing up. We've practiced finding literary devices, understanding how poetry works in a story, and thinking about how these themes relate to our own lives.

parent_notes: The Crossover appeals to reluctant readers with its fast pace, basketball content, and accessible verse form. Reading aloud is essential — Alexander wrote it to be heard. The personal journal prompt about competition may surface real feelings about sibling dynamics.

title: Persuasive Writing — Anticipating Objections and Building Rebuttals
description: Students strengthen their persuasive essays by learning to anticipate and address counterarguments. They practice acknowledging opposing viewpoints while maintaining their position, using concession and rebuttal techniques.
instructions:
1. Review body paragraphs from Day 3.
2. Introduce counterarguments: what someone who disagrees would say.
3. Explain why addressing counterarguments strengthens your essay.
4. Model the concession-rebuttal pattern.
5. Practice identifying counterarguments to various thesis statements.
6. Model writing a counterargument paragraph.
7. Discuss dismissing vs. respectfully addressing opposing views.
8. Students identify counterarguments to their own thesis.
9. Draft a counterargument-rebuttal paragraph.
10. Peer review for fairness and effectiveness.

slides.heading: Counterarguments and Rebuttals
slides.subheading: Strengthening Your Argument by Addressing the Other Side
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this first slide is introducing a super important idea for making your writing really strong: "Counterarguments and Rebuttals." Think of it like this: you've got your main idea, right? Well, a counterargument is like someone else saying, "But what about THIS point?" and a rebuttal is you explaining why your idea is still the best, even with that other point in mind.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare counterargument-rebuttal examples. Create a concession-rebuttal language reference. Have students gather their work from previous days.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us all the stuff we'll need for today's lesson. We've got some example paragraphs that show how to handle counterarguments, a handy sheet with phrases to use when you agree a little bit before disagreeing, your own essays from earlier, a guide for debating, and just some regular paper and pencils. Make sure you have all these things ready to go so we can get started.

slides.text: A counterargument is the strongest case AGAINST your position. Addressing it shows intellectual honesty: you have considered other perspectives and still believe your thesis. Ignoring counterarguments makes your essay weaker because readers will think of them anyway.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what's a counterargument? It's basically the *strongest* thing someone could say to argue *against* what you believe. The slide is telling us that when you show you've thought about these opposing ideas and can still explain why your point is valid, your whole argument becomes way more convincing and shows you've really thought things through.

slides.text: The concession-rebuttal pattern: CONCEDE the valid point: 'While it is true that globalization creates low-wage jobs...' Then REBUT: '...these jobs have lifted millions out of subsistence farming, and the solution is better standards, not less trade.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn the magic trick: the concession-rebuttal pattern. First, you "concede" – that means you admit the other side has a good point, using phrases like "It's true that..." Then, you "rebut" – you explain why, even with that point, your original idea still holds up, like saying "...but here's why that doesn't change the main issue."

slides.text: Use respectful concession words: Admittedly, It is true that, Opponents make a valid point... Then pivot: However, Nevertheless, Yet the evidence suggests... This shows maturity and builds credibility.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make your writing sound smart and fair, you need to use special "concession words." The slide lists some good ones like "Admittedly" or "It is true that" to show you understand the other side. Then, you use words like "However" or "Nevertheless" to smoothly transition back to why your point is stronger.

slides.text: Finding counterarguments: Ask what someone who disagrees would say. Engage with the strongest version of the opposing view, not a weak one. A strong rebuttal defeats a strong counterargument, not a straw man.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about figuring out what someone *against* your idea would say. The best way to do this is to imagine the strongest possible argument they could make, not some easy one you can easily beat. You want to practice arguing against the toughest points to make your own argument shine.

slides.prompt: Build counterargument skills: (1) Exchange thesis statements with a partner and write the strongest counterargument against theirs. (2) Review the counterargument written for YOUR thesis. (3) Draft a counterargument-rebuttal paragraph. (4) Peer review for fairness and effectiveness.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put this into practice! You're going to swap your main idea (thesis statement) with a friend and help each other think of the *toughest* argument against it. Then, you'll work on writing a whole paragraph where you admit the other side has a point (concede) and then explain why your idea is still better (rebut).

slides.text: The strongest arguments survive the challenge of counterarguments. By addressing opposing views, you show that your position is based on careful consideration, not ignorance of alternatives.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify counterarguments, write a concession-rebuttal paragraph, and evaluate whether opposing views are fairly addressed?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up by thinking about how strong your argument is. The slide reminds us that facing challenges and addressing opposing ideas makes your writing much more powerful because it shows you've considered all sides. It’s like showing your work in math – it proves you know what you’re talking about.

parent_notes: Teaching counterarguments develops intellectual humility and critical thinking. Practice at home by playing devil's advocate when your child states an opinion. The partner exchange exercise is powerful because students find it easier to argue against someone else's position.

title: Multiplying and Dividing Integers — Patterns and Rules
description: Students discover the rules for multiplying and dividing integers by exploring patterns. They learn that the sign rules are consistent and logical, then apply these operations to multi-step problems and real-world scenarios.
instructions:
1. Review integer addition and subtraction from Day 3.
2. Explore multiplication patterns to discover rules.
3. Discover the rule: positive times negative equals negative.
4. Extend: negative times negative equals positive.
5. Summarize sign rules: same signs positive, different signs negative.
6. Apply the same rules to division.
7. Solve multi-step problems with mixed operations.
8. Apply to real-world contexts: rate of change, loss over time.
9. Students practice multiplication and division of integers.
10. Challenge: order of operations with integers.

slides.heading: Multiplying and Dividing Integers
slides.subheading: Discovering the Sign Rules
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into multiplying and dividing with negative numbers, which we call integers. It's going to show us how to figure out the "sign rules" so we always know if our answer should be positive or negative. Think of it as learning the secret code for math!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the multiplication pattern chart. Print sign rules reference cards. Have calculators available for verification.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this next part, we need a few tools to help us discover these rules. You'll need that "Integer multiplication pattern chart" – it's like a cheat sheet that shows us what happens. We've also got a "Sign rules reference card" to keep the big ideas handy, a "Number line" to visualize the numbers, and a "Calculator" just for double-checking our work later. Grab your "Pencils" and "Practice worksheet" too!

slides.text: Discover the pattern: 3 x 3 = 9, 3 x 2 = 6, 3 x 1 = 3, 3 x 0 = 0. Each time we multiply by one less, the product decreases by 3. So 3 x (-1) = -3 and 3 x (-2) = -6. Positive times negative equals negative.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is where we become math detectives and find a pattern! Look at the examples: 3 times 3 is 9, then 3 times 2 is 6. See how as the number we multiply by gets smaller (from 3 to 2), the answer also gets smaller? The instruction tells us this pattern continues, so when we multiply by a negative number, like 3 times -1, the answer has to keep going down, which is why it becomes -3. This shows us that when you multiply a positive number by a negative number, the answer is always negative.

slides.text: Extend with negatives: (-3) x 3 = -9, (-3) x 2 = -6, (-3) x 1 = -3, (-3) x 0 = 0. Each decrease by one increases the product by 3. So (-3) x (-1) = 3 and (-3) x (-2) = 6. Negative times negative equals positive.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to do the same detective work but start with a negative number, like -3. We're multiplying -3 by 3, then by 2, then by 1, and so on. Notice how the answers are getting bigger (from -9 up to 0)? The pattern here tells us that when you decrease the number you're multiplying by, the answer actually *increases*. So, when we multiply two negative numbers together, like -3 times -1, the answer has to keep increasing, which makes it positive (3)!

slides.text: The sign rules: SAME signs (both positive or both negative) give a POSITIVE result. DIFFERENT signs give a NEGATIVE result. This works for both multiplication AND division.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important summary slide! It's telling us the big rule for both multiplying and dividing integers: if the two numbers you're working with have the *same* sign (both positive or both negative), your answer will always be positive. But if they have *different* signs (one positive and one negative), your answer will always be negative. Keep this rule handy, because it's the key to everything.

slides.text: Multi-step: (-2) x (-3) x (-4) = ? Work left to right: (-2) x (-3) = +6, then (+6) x (-4) = -24. Shortcut: count negative signs. EVEN negatives give positive. ODD negatives give negative.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how to handle problems with more than one step, like multiplying three numbers together. The trick is to just go from left to right, just like you usually read. So, you figure out the first two numbers, get that answer, and then use that answer to multiply by the third number. There's also a cool shortcut: just count how many negative signs there are. If there's an even number of them, your final answer is positive; if there's an odd number, it's negative.

slides.prompt: Master integer multiplication and division: (1) Solve 15 mixed problems. (2) Calculate (-1) to powers 1 through 10 and describe the pattern. (3) Real-world: Stock loses $3/day for 5 days — total? Submarine descends 50m/min for 8 min — depth? (4) Order of operations: Solve (-3) squared + 4 x (-2) - (-5).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put all our new skills to the test! We've got a bunch of mixed problems to solve, a fun puzzle about powers of -1 (see if you can spot the pattern!), and a couple of real-world scenarios where you'll use these rules, like figuring out money loss or how deep something goes. Then, there's a challenge problem that mixes in exponents and subtraction, so remember that order of operations we learned!

slides.text: The sign rules emerge from logical patterns. Same signs give positive; different signs give negative. This consistency is what makes mathematics trustworthy.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student multiply and divide integers using sign rules, solve multi-step problems, and apply operations to real-world contexts?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've made it to the end! This slide reminds us that the math rules we discovered aren't random; they make sense and follow logical patterns, which is why we can trust them. You've practiced multiplying and dividing integers, figured out multi-step problems, and even applied them to real-life situations. Great job mastering these rules!

parent_notes: The pattern-discovery approach helps students understand WHY negative times negative equals positive. Practice with real contexts: stock changes, temperature drops, diving depths. If your child asks why the rules work, encourage them to return to the pattern.

title: Water Quality and Pollution — Testing and Protecting Our Water
description: Students investigate water quality by learning about common pollutants, testing methods, and the impact of pollution on ecosystems and human health. They conduct water quality tests and analyze how human activities affect water systems.
instructions:
1. Connect to air quality from Day 2.
2. Define water pollution: contamination that degrades water quality.
3. Identify sources: agricultural runoff, industrial discharge, sewage, plastic.
4. Explain water quality indicators: pH, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, nitrates.
5. Demonstrate water quality testing with test strips.
6. Discuss the water cycle and how pollutants travel.
7. Examine case studies: Flint water crisis, ocean plastic.
8. Students test water samples and record data.
9. Analyze results against safe drinking water standards.
10. Design a water protection plan.
materials_needed: Water quality test strips or kit

slides.heading: Water Quality and Pollution
slides.subheading: Testing and Protecting Our Most Vital Resource
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title of what we're learning about today: "Water Quality and Pollution," and it's calling water our "most vital resource." Think of it like the introduction to a cool story – it's setting the scene for why this topic is super important for all of us.

items: Water quality test strips or kit
slides.setup_instructions: Obtain a basic water quality testing kit. Collect samples from different sources. Ensure safety goggles are available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool stuff we'll need for our water testing adventure! We've got test strips to check the water's health, different water samples like tap water and maybe some from outside, a chart to help us understand the numbers, a diagram about pollution, a sheet to write everything down, pencils, and safety goggles to protect our eyes. Make sure you have a grown-up help you gather all these things before we start.

slides.text: Water pollution comes from POINT sources (specific locations like a factory pipe) and NON-POINT sources (diffuse, like agricultural runoff from many farms). Non-point pollution is harder to control because it comes from everywhere.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is teaching us about where water pollution comes from. Some pollution is easy to point to, like a pipe coming out of a factory – that's a "point source." But other pollution, like rain washing fertilizer off a whole bunch of farms, is harder to find because it's spread out – that's a "non-point source," and it's a bigger challenge to deal with.

slides.text: Water quality indicators: pH measures acidity (safe: 6.5-8.5). Dissolved oxygen sustains aquatic life (below 4 mg/L, fish die). Turbidity measures cloudiness. Nitrates from fertilizer cause algal blooms creating dead zones.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're learning about the signs of healthy or unhealthy water. We'll look at things like pH, which tells us if water is acidic or basic, dissolved oxygen that fish need to breathe, turbidity which is how cloudy the water is, and nitrates, which can cause gross algae to grow. These are like the vital signs for our water.

slides.text: The Flint, Michigan water crisis showed water quality is a justice issue. Switching water sources corroded lead pipes, contaminating water for 100,000 people. Children suffered permanent brain damage from lead poisoning.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is a serious reminder about the Flint, Michigan water crisis. It shows how something as simple as changing water sources can lead to big problems, like lead getting into the water pipes and making people sick, especially kids. It really highlights how important clean water is for everyone's health and fairness.

slides.text: The water cycle means pollution travels. Pesticides in Iowa wash into the Mississippi, travel 1,000 miles, and create a dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico the size of New Jersey. Everything connects through water.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a great example of how everything is connected through water. Pollution from farms way up north can travel down rivers, all the way to the ocean, creating huge "dead zones" where nothing can live. It shows us that what happens in one place can affect places thousands of miles away.

slides.prompt: Conduct water quality tests: (1) Test three samples for pH and other indicators. Record data. (2) Compare to safe standards. (3) Research one case study: Flint, Pacific Garbage Patch, or Gulf dead zone. Summarize causes, effects, solutions. (4) Design a 3-action water protection plan.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where the action happens! You're going to use those test strips to check the water samples you collected for things like pH and cloudiness, and then write down your findings. After that, you'll compare your results to see if the water is safe, and then pick one of the case studies to learn more about. Finally, you'll get to be creative and design your own plan to help protect water!

slides.text: Clean water requires constant monitoring, protection, and investment. Water quality connects chemistry, biology, and social justice. Understanding it empowers informed citizenship.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain water pollution types, conduct tests, interpret results, and propose solutions?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is wrapping everything up by reminding us that keeping our water clean is an ongoing job that needs everyone's attention and effort. It connects science, like chemistry and biology, with making sure everyone has access to clean water. Understanding water quality helps us all be better citizens who can make smart choices.

parent_notes: Water quality testing is engaging hands-on science. Basic test kits cost under $15 at pet stores. If you have a local stream, testing that water makes the lesson more meaningful. The Flint crisis example connects science to social justice.

title: Global Art Movements — Street Art and Muralism as Social Commentary
description: Students explore how street art and muralism serve as tools for social commentary and cultural expression worldwide. They analyze works by Banksy, Diego Rivera, and local muralists, then design their own socially-conscious mural.
instructions:
1. Connect to world music from Day 2.
2. Introduce muralism: large-scale public art with social messages.
3. Study Diego Rivera's murals and public art vision.
4. Examine modern street art: Banksy, Shepard Fairey, JR.
5. Discuss: Is street art vandalism or art?
6. Analyze social messages in specific artworks.
7. Discuss how location affects meaning.
8. Students design a mural concept addressing a social issue.
9. Create a scaled mural sketch with symbolism.
10. Present and explain artistic choices.
materials_needed: Muralism and street art examples (printed images)

slides.heading: Street Art and Muralism
slides.subheading: Art as Social Commentary
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to be learning about: street art and murals, and how artists use them to talk about important things happening in the world. Think of it like the title page of a cool book that tells you what adventures you're about to go on.

items: Muralism and street art examples (printed images)
slides.setup_instructions: Print images of Rivera murals, Banksy works, and community murals. Prepare large drawing paper. Create mural planning templates.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like our "what you need to create awesome art" checklist. We've got printed pictures of famous murals and street art to look at for inspiration, big paper for our own masterpiece, colored pencils and markers to make it pop, rulers to help keep things straight, and a special planning sheet to help us map out our ideas before we start drawing. Make sure you have all these things ready to go!

slides.text: Muralism has a long history as the people's art. Diego Rivera painted massive murals on public buildings in Mexico, telling the story of workers, indigenous peoples, and revolution. His art was free for everyone — no museum ticket required.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us about the history of muralism, like how long ago artists started painting big pictures on walls for everyone to see, not just in fancy museums. It's talking about Diego Rivera, a famous artist who painted huge murals in Mexico about everyday people and big changes, making art accessible to everybody.

slides.text: Modern street art continues this tradition. Banksy uses humor and irony to comment on war and capitalism. JR pastes giant photographs making the invisible visible. Shepard Fairey's Hope poster showed how street art enters mainstream politics.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're jumping to modern times and looking at street art, which is kind of like muralism's younger, edgier sibling. It mentions artists like Banksy, who uses stencils and humor to make us think, and JR, who puts huge photos in public places to tell people's stories. These artists are still using public spaces to share messages, just like Rivera did.

slides.text: Is street art vandalism or art? Painting on buildings without permission raises questions about public space, property rights, and visual expression. Community-commissioned murals are clearly art. The boundary raises important questions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part asks a really interesting question: is putting art on a building without permission graffiti, or is it actual art? It points out that when a community asks for a mural, it's definitely art, but when someone paints on a wall without asking, it gets a bit blurry. It's a good discussion to have about what art is and where it belongs.

slides.text: Symbolism is muralism's language. Rivera used corn for indigenous culture, broken chains for liberation. Banksy uses rats for outcasts and children for innocence. Your mural should use symbols that communicate visually, even without words.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about the secret language of murals: symbols! It explains that artists use things like corn or broken chains to represent bigger ideas, just like Banksy uses rats or kids. Your mural will need to use symbols too, so people can understand your message just by looking at the pictures.

slides.prompt: Design a mural: (1) Choose a social issue you care about. (2) Plan: central message, symbols, colors, ideal location. (3) Create a scaled sketch with at least 3 symbolic elements and a meaningful color scheme. (4) Write an artist's statement explaining your choices.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the artist! You'll pick a social issue you care about, like the environment or fairness, and then plan out your own mural idea. Think about the main message, what symbols you'll use, what colors fit your message, and where it would look best, then draw a sketch of it, making sure to include at least three symbols.

slides.text: Art does not live only in museums. From cave paintings to modern murals, humans have used walls to tell stories, challenge power, and imagine a better world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze social messages in muralism, use symbolism intentionally, and articulate how choices communicate commentary?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is wrapping things up by reminding us that art has always been a way for people to share stories, make us think, and even dream of a better world, not just in museums but everywhere. It’s checking to see if you can now understand the messages in murals, use symbols like a pro, and explain how your art choices say something important.

parent_notes: Street art engages upper elementary students by connecting art to social issues. Look for local murals in your community. The vandalism debate develops critical thinking about public space. The design project lets students express what they care about through visual symbols.

title: Digital Citizenship — Navigating Information and Misinformation Online
description: Students develop critical media literacy skills for evaluating online information. They learn to identify reliable sources, recognize misinformation and bias, and practice responsible digital citizenship in an age of information overload.
instructions:
1. Connect to ethical consumption from Day 2.
2. Discuss the information landscape today.
3. Define misinformation vs. disinformation.
4. Teach the CRAAP test for evaluating sources.
5. Practice evaluating real websites.
6. Discuss confirmation bias.
7. Examine social media algorithms and echo chambers.
8. Practice fact-checking techniques.
9. Students evaluate articles on a globalization topic.
10. Create a personal digital citizenship pledge.
materials_needed: Sample websites and articles (reliable and unreliable)

slides.heading: Digital Citizenship
slides.subheading: Navigating Information and Misinformation
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title page for our lesson. It's introducing us to the big idea of "Digital Citizenship," which is all about how we act online, especially when we're looking at all the stuff people post. Think of it like being a good citizen in a town, but the town is the internet!

items: Sample websites and articles (reliable and unreliable)
slides.setup_instructions: Curate articles from reliable and unreliable sources. Print CRAAP test forms. Prepare a fact-checking guide. Bookmark fact-checking websites.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists all the cool tools we'll need for our online adventure today. We've got sample websites and articles – some good, some tricky – to help us practice. The CRAAP test form is like a checklist to help us figure out if a website is trustworthy, and the fact-checking guide is our secret weapon against fake news. You'll also need a computer or tablet to explore, and pencils for taking notes.

slides.text: Today, anyone can publish anything online. This is both miraculous and dangerous. You have access to the world's knowledge but also an ocean of misinformation. The most important 21st-century skill is telling the difference.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is setting the scene for why this lesson is super important. Imagine the internet is like a giant library where anyone can add a book, even if it's full of made-up stuff. We have access to tons of amazing information, but we also have to be careful not to believe everything we read. Learning to spot what's real and what's not is one of the most useful skills you can have today.

slides.text: The CRAAP test: CURRENCY — When published? Is it current? RELEVANCE — Does it address your topic? AUTHORITY — Who wrote it and what are their credentials? ACCURACY — Is it supported by evidence? PURPOSE — Why was it written: to inform, persuade, sell, or entertain?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces the CRAAP test, which is a clever way to check if information you find online is reliable. It stands for Currency (how new is it?), Relevance (does it actually answer your question?), Authority (who wrote it and are they an expert?), Accuracy (is it true and backed up by facts?), and Purpose (why was this written – to teach, sell, or trick you?). We'll use this test to grade websites!

slides.text: Confirmation bias is your brain's tendency to believe information that agrees with your existing views. Awareness is the first step to overcoming it. Actively seek perspectives that challenge your thinking.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this step talks about something called "confirmation bias." Basically, our brains like to agree with things we already believe, which can sometimes trick us into accepting false information if it sounds right. The best way to fight this is to be aware of it and make an effort to look at different viewpoints, even if they seem a little strange at first.

slides.text: Fact-checking: Read ABOUT the source, not just the article. Check if other reliable sources agree. Look for original data. Be suspicious of emotional language and anonymous sources. Use lateral reading — multiple tabs to verify claims.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our guide to fact-checking, which is like being a detective for information! Instead of just reading an article, we'll learn to look *around* it. That means checking out who wrote it, seeing if other trusted sources say the same thing, and being wary of super emotional language or articles with no author. We'll even use multiple browser tabs to compare information, which is called "lateral reading."

slides.prompt: Evaluate information: (1) Apply CRAAP test to 4 articles, rating each criterion 1-5. (2) Verify one claim from each article using another source. (3) Find biased language in one article and rewrite it neutrally. (4) Create a Digital Citizenship Pledge with 5 responsible information commitments.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we get to put all our new detective skills to the test! You'll look at four different articles, using the CRAAP test to see how trustworthy they are. Then, you'll pick one claim from each article and use the internet to see if it's true. You'll also try to find some biased language and rewrite it fairly. Finally, you'll create your own personal promise, like a pledge, about how you'll be a responsible digital citizen online.

slides.text: Digital citizenship means taking responsibility for how you consume and share information. Evaluating sources, checking facts, and recognizing bias is as important as reading itself.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply the CRAAP test, identify misinformation, demonstrate fact-checking skills, and articulate digital citizenship principles?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide wraps up our lesson by reminding us that being a good digital citizen means being smart about what we read and share online. It's super important to check where our information comes from, make sure it's accurate, and understand why it was created. You've learned how to be a critical thinker online, which is a superpower in today's world!

parent_notes: Media literacy is an essential modern skill. The CRAAP test is used in university libraries and is a lifetime tool. Model good information habits at home. Consider establishing family guidelines for evaluating and sharing information online.

title: Persuasive Writing — Conclusions and Final Revision
description: Students learn to write powerful conclusions for their persuasive essays and complete a final revision. They practice restating the thesis, summarizing key arguments, and ending with a call to action or thought-provoking statement.
instructions:
1. Review essay components from the week.
2. Introduce the conclusion and its purpose.
3. Model conclusion techniques: restate thesis, summarize, call to action.
4. Discuss common conclusion mistakes.
5. Analyze conclusion examples from published essays.
6. Students draft their conclusion paragraph.
7. Full essay read-through for logical flow.
8. Practice revision strategies: read aloud, check transitions.
9. Final revision and editing.
10. Share completed essays.
materials_needed: Complete essay drafts from previous days

slides.heading: Persuasive Conclusions
slides.subheading: Ending with Impact
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is all about how to wrap up your persuasive writing. Think of it like the grand finale of a fireworks show – it needs to be exciting and leave a lasting impression! We're going to learn how to make your ending super strong so your reader totally agrees with you.

items: Complete essay drafts from previous days
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare strong conclusion examples. Create a comprehensive revision checklist. Have students gather all essay components.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so here's what you'll need for this part. You've got some example conclusions to look at, which are like secret weapons for seeing what works. The revision checklist is a map to make sure your whole essay is awesome. You'll also need your essay drafts from before, a guide for editing marks (like little symbols to fix things), paper, pencils, and some colored pens to make your edits really clear.

slides.text: The conclusion is your last chance to persuade. It should NOT repeat the introduction. It should feel like the natural destination of your argument, making the reader think, 'I am convinced.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Your conclusion is like the last handshake with your reader, and it's super important. It's not just about repeating what you said in the beginning; it's about showing how your ideas have grown and why your argument is the best. You want your reader to finish reading and think, "Wow, they've convinced me!"

slides.text: Three techniques: (1) Restate your thesis in DIFFERENT words, showing your argument has deepened. (2) Summarize your strongest points BRIEFLY. (3) End with a CALL TO ACTION or thought-provoking question extending beyond the essay.
slides.mascot_explanation: There are three main tricks for a killer conclusion. First, say your main idea (your thesis) again, but in totally new words, showing you understand it even better now. Second, quickly remind them of your best points, just the highlights. Finally, end with a bang – either tell them what you want them to *do* or ask a question that makes them keep thinking about your topic.

slides.text: Example: 'Globalization is neither purely beneficial nor entirely harmful — it is a powerful force requiring thoughtful management. Fair trade, cultural preservation, and environmental regulation can harness its benefits while minimizing its costs. The question is not whether to engage with the global economy, but how to do so justly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This example shows how to finish strong. It restates the idea that globalization isn't all good or all bad, then it briefly mentions ways to manage it well, and finishes with a question that makes you think about *how* we should participate globally. See how it doesn't just stop, but makes you ponder?

slides.text: Final revision: Read aloud — your ear catches what your eye misses. Check every paragraph's connection to the thesis, transition smoothness, evidence accuracy, counterargument fairness, and conclusion impact.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the final polish on your whole essay. The best way to catch mistakes is to read your essay out loud – your ears can hear things your eyes might miss. Go through each part and make sure it connects to your main point, that the ideas flow smoothly, your facts are right, and your conclusion really packs a punch.

slides.prompt: Complete your essay: (1) Write a conclusion using at least two techniques. (2) Assemble the full essay. (3) Read aloud and mark awkward passages. (4) Apply the revision checklist systematically. (5) Create a clean final draft.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, here's your mission: write that conclusion using at least two of those cool techniques we just talked about. Then, put your whole essay together, read it aloud to catch any awkward spots, use your checklist to make sure everything is perfect, and write out a super clean final copy. You've got 25 minutes to make this essay shine!

slides.text: You have built a complete persuasive essay: thesis, evidence-based body paragraphs, counterargument, and conclusion. This is writing that changes minds and earns respect.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write an effective conclusion and revise a complete persuasive essay for logic, evidence, transitions, and clarity?
slides.mascot_explanation: You totally rocked this! You've built a complete persuasive essay from start to finish, with a strong argument, solid evidence, and now a powerful conclusion. You've learned how to write something that can actually change someone's mind and show how thoughtful you are. That's some serious writing power you've got there!

parent_notes: This lesson brings together the week of persuasive writing. The revision process is as important as drafting. Reading aloud is surprisingly effective. Celebrate the completed essay — it represents a significant academic achievement. Save it in a portfolio to track growth.

title: Integer Operations Review — Mixed Problems and Applications
description: Students consolidate all four integer operations through mixed practice, word problems, and real-world applications. They apply order of operations with integers and connect to coordinate graphing and algebraic thinking.
instructions:
1. Review all integer operation rules.
2. Practice mixed operations problems.
3. Apply order of operations (PEMDAS) with integers.
4. Solve multi-step word problems.
5. Connect integers to coordinate graphing in all four quadrants.
6. Explore integer patterns and sequences.
7. Apply integers to real-world data sets.
8. Students complete a mixed integer challenge.
9. Create real-world integer problems for peers.
10. Reflect on how integers expand the number system.

slides.heading: Integer Operations Mastery
slides.subheading: Mixed Practice and Real-World Connections
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure with integers! It's telling us we're going to get really good at adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing with negative numbers, and then see how they help us solve real puzzles in the world around us. Think of it as leveling up our math skills to a whole new level.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a comprehensive mixed practice worksheet. Print coordinate plane graph paper. Compile real-world data sets.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists everything we'll need for our integer journey. We've got a reference card to remind us of the rules, graph paper for plotting points, and a calculator just to double-check our answers. We also have a worksheet with practice problems, some cool real-world data, and pencils to do all the work.

slides.text: Review: ADDITION — same signs: add and keep sign; different signs: subtract and keep bigger sign. SUBTRACTION — Keep-Change-Change. MULTIPLICATION and DIVISION — same signs: positive; different signs: negative.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about remembering the basic rules for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing integers. For addition and subtraction, it's about paying attention to whether the numbers have the same sign or different signs, and for multiplication and division, it's about remembering that same signs give you a positive answer and different signs give you a negative one.

slides.text: Order of operations with integers: PEMDAS still applies. (-3) squared = 9 (square first, result is positive). But -(3 squared) = -9 (square first, then negate). Parentheses matter enormously.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're diving into the order of operations, also known as PEMDAS, but with our integer rules. It's super important to remember that parentheses change things, and squaring a negative number makes it positive, like (-3) squared is 9, but if the negative sign is outside the parentheses, like -(3 squared), the answer is -9.

slides.text: Integers unlock the coordinate plane. Quadrant I: (+, +). Quadrant II: (-, +). Quadrant III: (-, -). Quadrant IV: (+, -). Every point can be described with integer coordinates.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how integers are like the secret code for the coordinate plane, which looks like a big grid with four sections called quadrants. Each point on the grid is found using two numbers, an x-coordinate and a y-coordinate, and knowing whether they are positive or negative tells us exactly which quadrant the point is in.

slides.text: Integer sequences reveal patterns: -10, -6, -2, 2, 6 (add 4 each time). Or 1, -2, 4, -8, 16 (multiply by -2). Finding patterns in sequences is the beginning of algebraic thinking.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at number sequences, which are just lists of numbers that follow a rule, and see how integers help us find that rule. For example, if we see numbers going up by 4 each time, like -10, -6, -2, we know we're adding 4, and figuring out these patterns is a first step to understanding algebra.

slides.prompt: Integer mastery challenge: (1) Solve 10 mixed problems with order of operations. (2) Plot A(3,-4), B(-2,5), C(-4,-3), D(0,-6), E(5,0) and identify quadrants. (3) Find the pattern: -20, -13, -6, 1, 8, ___, ___. Also: 2, -6, 18, -54, ___, ___. (4) Create a 5-problem real-world challenge and trade with a partner.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our big challenge activity where we get to show off all the cool stuff we've learned! We'll solve some mixed problems, plot points on the coordinate plane, figure out some tricky number patterns, and even create our own real-world problems for a partner to solve, so get ready to put your math skills to the test!

slides.text: Integers doubled the number system and opened doors to coordinate graphing, algebra, and real-world problem solving. You now command the full number line.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student perform all four integer operations, apply order of operations, plot points in all quadrants, and create real-world integer problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything we've accomplished! We've basically learned a whole new language of numbers with integers, which lets us explore things like graphing and algebra, and even understand real-world situations better. You've totally mastered the number line and all the operations that come with it!

parent_notes: This review consolidates an important milestone. Fluency with integers is essential for pre-algebra. The coordinate plane is particularly important for graphing. Practice at home: track temperatures, manage mock budgets, or play Battleship-style coordinate games.

title: Globalization Debate — Winners, Losers, and the Path Forward
description: Students synthesize their understanding of globalization by examining its winners and losers, evaluating different perspectives, and debating the future direction of global integration with evidence from the week.
instructions:
1. Review economic and cultural globalization.
2. Identify globalization's winners and losers.
3. Examine case studies from different perspectives.
4. Discuss inequality within globalization.
5. Examine anti-globalization movements.
6. Discuss possible futures for global integration.
7. Prepare debate positions with evidence.
8. Conduct a structured debate.
9. Debrief and discuss the strongest arguments.
10. Write a personal reflection.

slides.heading: Globalization Debate
slides.subheading: Winners, Losers, and the Path Forward
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title page for our big project: a debate about globalization. It's basically asking us to think about whether globalization, which is like the world becoming more connected, has been a good thing overall, and what that means for the future. We'll be looking at who benefits and who gets left behind.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare case study cards. Create debate worksheets. Compile evidence from the week.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide lists all the stuff we'll need for our debate. We've got these case study cards which are like little stories about globalization's effects, a worksheet to help us organize our thoughts for the debate, notes we took earlier in the week to use as evidence, and a guide that explains the debate rules. You'll also need your journal and pencils to write things down.

slides.text: Globalization creates winners and losers simultaneously. Consumers benefit from cheap goods, but workers making those goods may earn $2/day. Tech companies connect the world, but local businesses may be destroyed by global competition.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us that globalization is a bit of a mixed bag – it creates winners and losers at the same time. For example, we get cheaper stuff to buy, which is awesome, but the people making those goods might be working for really low wages, which isn't so great. It’s like getting a cool new toy but knowing someone had a really hard time making it.

slides.text: Since 1990, over 1 billion people have risen out of extreme poverty, largely through trade. But the richest 1% own more than the bottom 50%. Globalization grew the economic pie, but the slices are far from equal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're looking at some big numbers about how globalization has affected poverty and wealth. It's true that a lot of people have gotten out of extreme poverty because of trade, which is a huge win! But, at the same time, the gap between the super-rich and everyone else has gotten much wider. Think of it like baking a giant cake – globalization made the cake bigger, but some people got way bigger slices than others.

slides.text: Anti-globalization movements argue trade serves corporations over people, cultural diversity is lost, and environmental destruction follows growth. Brexit and economic nationalism show many people feel left behind.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about the flip side – the people who aren't fans of globalization. They worry that big companies get all the benefits, that unique cultures are disappearing because everything is becoming the same, and that making all these goods is hurting the planet. You might have heard about things like Brexit or people wanting their country to focus more on itself; that's part of this anti-globalization idea.

slides.text: Three possible futures: (1) MORE globalization — deeper integration. (2) DEGLOBALIZATION — nations turn inward. (3) REFORMED globalization — trade with stronger protections for workers, environment, and culture.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're thinking about what could happen next with globalization. The slide lays out three paths: we could have *even more* connection between countries, or countries could decide to pull back and focus more on themselves (that's deglobalization), or we could find a middle ground where we still trade but with rules to make sure things are fairer for workers, the environment, and different cultures.

slides.prompt: Structured debate: (1) Choose PRO or CON on whether globalization has done more good than harm. (2) Prepare thesis, 3 evidence points, and a counterargument response. (3) Present (3 min), respond (2 min), close (1 min). (4) Write a reflection: What is your honest assessment? Has your view changed this week?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we get to put everything we've learned into action with a debate! You'll pick a side – either arguing that globalization has done more good than harm, or the opposite. Then, you'll use the evidence you've gathered to build your argument, thinking about what the other side might say and how you'll respond. You'll get a few minutes to present your case, then a bit of time to discuss, and finally, you'll write down your honest thoughts on how you feel about globalization now.

slides.text: Globalization is not something that happens TO us — it is something we shape through choices, votes, and values. Understanding its complexity prepares you to advocate for a global economy that works for everyone.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze globalization from multiple perspectives, use evidence in debate, and articulate a nuanced personal view?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is a reminder that globalization isn't just something that happens to us; we all have a part in shaping it through our choices and what we believe in. Understanding all the different sides, the good and the bad, helps us figure out how to make the world a better, fairer place for everyone. It's asking if you can now look at globalization from different angles, use what you learned to argue your point, and explain your own thoughts clearly.

parent_notes: This synthesis brings the week together through meaningful debate. The topic is genuinely complex with reasonable disagreement. Encourage your child to share their reflection. The three-futures framework helps children think about the world they want to build.

title: Environmental Science — Climate Change Science and Evidence
description: Students examine the scientific evidence for climate change, understanding the greenhouse effect, analyzing temperature data, and evaluating the connections between human activity and global warming.
instructions:
1. Connect to air and water quality from the week.
2. Explain the greenhouse effect.
3. Identify key greenhouse gases and their sources.
4. Examine temperature data over 150 years.
5. Discuss evidence: ice cores, sea level, glacier retreat, species migration.
6. Explain the scientific consensus.
7. Distinguish weather from climate.
8. Students analyze temperature and CO2 data.
9. Create a greenhouse effect diagram.
10. Discuss evidence-based solutions.

slides.heading: Climate Change Science
slides.subheading: Understanding the Evidence
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into climate change. It's introducing the main topic: understanding the science and the evidence behind why our planet's climate is changing. Think of it as setting the stage for everything we're about to learn.

slides.setup_instructions: Print NASA temperature graphs and CO2 data. Prepare diagram templates. Create evidence summary cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is a "get ready" list for our activity. It tells us we'll need some graphs showing temperature and CO2 over time, a template to draw the greenhouse effect, some cards with important facts, and basic art supplies like paper and pencils. You'll need to gather these materials, maybe with a grown-up's help, so we have everything we need to do the cool science stuff later.

slides.text: The greenhouse effect is essential for life: without it, Earth would be far too cold. Greenhouse gases trap heat. The problem is the ENHANCED greenhouse effect from human activities adding extra gases to the atmosphere.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step explains the "greenhouse effect." Imagine Earth wearing a cozy blanket – that's what certain gases in our atmosphere do; they trap some of the sun's heat to keep us warm enough to live. The slide points out that the problem isn't the natural greenhouse effect, but that humans are adding *extra* gases, making the blanket too thick and warming things up too much.

slides.text: The evidence: Global temperature has risen about 1.1 degrees Celsius since 1880. CO2 has increased from 280 ppm to over 420 ppm — the highest in 800,000 years. Ice cores from Antarctica trap ancient air bubbles for analysis.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part dives into the actual evidence! It tells us that the Earth's temperature has gone up quite a bit, and the amount of a gas called CO2 in the air is higher than it's been in almost a million years. It also mentions these super cool "ice cores" from Antarctica, which are like frozen time capsules that scientists can study to see what the air was like way back when.

slides.text: Weather is not climate. A cold day does not disprove warming. Climate is the average over decades. Evidence: sea levels up 8 inches since 1900, Arctic ice shrinking 13% per decade, glaciers retreating worldwide, species migrating poleward.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a super important point: weather and climate are different! You know how it can be freezing one day but sunny the next? That's weather. Climate is the *average* weather over a really long time, like decades. The slide gives examples like sea levels rising, ice melting, and even animals moving to new places because their homes are getting too warm.

slides.text: Scientific consensus: 97% of publishing climate scientists agree on human-caused warming. Understanding the difference between scientific consensus and political debate is essential for informed citizenship.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about what most scientists agree on. It says that a huge majority of scientists who study climate are pretty sure that humans are causing the planet to warm up. It's important to know that this is based on lots of science and evidence, not just opinions, and it's different from arguments you might hear in politics.

slides.prompt: Analyze climate evidence: (1) Examine the temperature graph. Describe the trend. (2) Compare temperature and CO2 graphs — what relationship do you see? (3) Create a greenhouse effect diagram showing solar radiation, trapped heat, and human sources. (4) Rate each evidence type 1-5 for persuasiveness and explain.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to be a climate detective! You'll look at the graphs to see if temperatures are going up or down and how that matches up with the CO2 levels. Then, you'll draw your own picture of the greenhouse effect, showing how the sun's energy works. Finally, you'll think about which pieces of evidence seem the most convincing to you and why.

slides.text: Climate science rests on evidence from thousands of scientists using ice cores, satellites, and weather stations. Understanding this evidence empowers informed conversations about your generation's most important challenge.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the greenhouse effect, analyze data trends, distinguish weather from climate, and evaluate scientific evidence?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is like a pat on the back for finishing the lesson. It reminds us that all this climate science is built on real evidence from tons of scientists using different tools. It says that understanding this evidence is super important for talking about the future and figuring out how we can help our planet.

parent_notes: This lesson focuses on scientific evidence, not policy. Understanding weather vs. climate is key. The data analysis develops scientific reasoning. The 97% consensus teaches how science works through evidence and peer review, not opinion.

title: Global Film and Storytelling — How Cinema Connects Cultures
description: Students explore filmmaking as a global storytelling medium. They analyze how different cultures tell stories through film, examine basic cinematic techniques, and create a storyboard for a short film about a globalization theme.
instructions:
1. Connect to world music and street art from the week.
2. Introduce cinema as the youngest major art form.
3. Discuss how film combines visual art, music, writing, and performance.
4. Examine filmmaking across cultures: Bollywood, anime, Nollywood.
5. Introduce cinematic techniques: camera angles, framing, editing.
6. Analyze a scene for filmmaker choices.
7. Discuss how film crosses language barriers.
8. Teach storyboard basics.
9. Create a storyboard for a globalization-themed short film.
10. Present storyboards and discuss choices.
materials_needed: Film clips or stills from world cinema

slides.heading: Global Cinema and Storytelling
slides.subheading: How Film Connects Cultures
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into movies! It's called "Global Cinema and Storytelling," and it's all about how movies, no matter where they're made, can help people all over the world understand each other better. Think of it as the introduction to a really cool documentary about movies themselves.

items: Film clips or stills from world cinema
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare stills from diverse cinema. Print 6-panel storyboard templates. Create a camera angle reference sheet.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing you all the cool tools we'll need for our filmmaking project. We've got film clips to watch for inspiration, a special template for drawing out our movie scenes called a storyboard, a guide to different camera shots, and all sorts of art supplies like colored pencils and markers. Your job is to grab all these things, maybe with a grown-up's help, so we're ready to get creative!

slides.text: Cinema is the most shared art form. Bollywood films reach a billion viewers. Pixar transcends language through visual storytelling. Anime has fans on every continent. Nollywood produces more films yearly than Hollywood.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us how HUGE movies are all over the world. It mentions Bollywood in India, which is massive, and even Pixar, whose movies we can understand without even knowing the language! It also points out that anime from Japan and movies from Nigeria, called Nollywood, are super popular too, showing that stories told on film can reach almost everyone.

slides.text: Every filmmaker choice creates meaning: A CLOSE-UP shows emotion. A WIDE SHOT shows context. A LOW ANGLE suggests power. A HIGH ANGLE suggests vulnerability. Nothing in a great film is accidental.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like getting a secret decoder ring for movies! It explains that every single choice a director makes, like zooming in close on an actor's face (that's a CLOSE-UP) or showing a whole big landscape (that's a WIDE SHOT), is meant to tell us something specific. They're showing us that a low angle makes someone look powerful, while a high angle can make them seem small or vulnerable.

slides.text: Different cultures have different film traditions. Bollywood integrates music and dance. Anime explores philosophy through distinctive visuals. Italian neorealism showed ordinary people. Each tradition reflects its culture's values.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're diving into how different countries make movies in their own special ways. Think about how Bollywood movies often have awesome song and dance numbers, or how anime uses really unique drawings and sometimes talks about big ideas. The slide explains that these different styles, like Italian neorealism showing everyday people, actually tell us a lot about what's important to people in those cultures.

slides.text: A storyboard is a filmmaker's blueprint — drawings showing each shot in sequence. Each panel shows camera angle, character positions, and notes about dialogue and sound. Clarity matters more than artistic perfection.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this is what a storyboard looks like! Imagine it's like a comic book version of your movie. Each little box, called a panel, is a drawing of one shot, showing where the camera is, where the characters are standing, and any important notes about what people are saying or what sounds we'll hear. Don't worry about making the drawings perfect; the important thing is to make your ideas clear.

slides.prompt: Create a storyboard: (1) Choose a globalization theme. (2) Plan 6 shots. For each: draw the scene, indicate camera angle, write dialogue, note sound. (3) Use at least 3 different camera angles. (4) Present your storyboard explaining cinematic choices.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make your own movie mini-plan! You get to pick a topic about how the world is connected, like how ideas travel or how different cultures share things. Then, you'll draw six scenes, using at least three different camera angles from our reference sheet, and add notes about what's happening. Just focus on showing your story clearly, and remember to explain your cool camera choices when you're done!

slides.text: Film combines visual art, music, writing, and performance into one storytelling experience. Understanding how filmmakers make choices makes you a more thoughtful viewer and powerful storyteller.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify cinematic techniques, compare film traditions, and create an effective storyboard?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us why all this movie stuff is so awesome. It says that film is like a super-combo of art, music, writing, and acting all rolled into one, and understanding how filmmakers make their choices helps us enjoy movies even more. Plus, it means *we* can become super storytellers ourselves by making thoughtful choices in our own work.

parent_notes: Film analysis develops visual literacy. The storyboard connects writing and art skills. Watch age-appropriate films from different cultures together and discuss the filmmaker's choices to transform passive watching into active analytical viewing.
